summary: NGT took a stern view of the lackadaisical attitude of the Ministry of Road, Transport and Highway as well as the Government of Uttarakhand for not even filing the muck dumping plan generated from the project. Court warns that no further adjournment would be granted in the case.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Judgement of the High Court of Kerala regarding grant of transit passes for extracting ordinary earth for construction of buildiings, Thrissur, Kerala, 04/04/2018
petitioner: Elko Properties And Developers Private Limited
respondent: District Geologist, Department of Mining And Geology, Thrissur District & Others
summary: The issue relates to refusal on the part of Department of Mining and Geology to accept the application of the Elko Properties for issuance of transit passes, so as to extract ordinary earth for building purposes citing the necessity of an environmental clearance certificate. Kerala High Court directs the Department of Mining and Geology not to insist on any environmental clearance certificate and states that Rule 14(2) of the of the Kerala Minor Mineral Concession Rules 2015 provides that no quarrying permit is required for extraction of ordinary earth in connection with the construction of residential buildings including flats or commercial buildings having a plinth area of 300M2 , if the owner of the land has obtained a valid permit for construction of the building from the Local Self Government Authorities concerned.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding illegalities committed in the utilization of funds allocated under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, Perambalur District, Tamil Nadu, 06/04/2018
summary: The issue relates to irregularities and illegalities committed in the utilization of funds allocated under the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme, Perambalur District, Tamil Nadu. Madras High Court notes that on an average, about Rs.80,000/- is being sanctioned for each beneficiary and that the funds allocated for a particular village panchayat appear to be substantial. District Collector - Perambalur District has been directed to submit an affidavit to the Court regarding the issue.

subject: Industry
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding industrial units in Mathura violating environmental norms, Uttar Pradesh, 06/04/2018
respondent: Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board & Others
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT directs District Administration, Mathura that those units who do not have consent to operate and according to the Pollution Control Board are not complying with environmental norms should not be allowed to operate any further.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding illegal commercial activity in and around R. K. Puram area of the Nallah, Delhi, 06/04/2018
respondent: Govt. of NCT of Delhi & Others
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: The case relates to illegal commercial activity going on in and around R.K. Puram area on the Nallah and no steps being taken by the South Delhi Municipal Corporation. According to the Applicant, such activity is resulting in blocking of the flow of water.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Order of the Bombay High Court regarding validity of Rule 6 (b) of the Seeds Rules, 1968, 09/04/2018
summary: Bombay High Court rules that it is not necessary to issue notice to the Attorney-General for India to declare Rule 6 (b) of the Seeds Rules, framed in exercise of the power conferred by the provision of Section 25(2)(f) of the Seeds Act, which is the Central legislation as unconstitutional or invalid.

subject: Water Resources
title: Supreme Court order regarding Cauvery water dispute, 09/04/2018
summary: upreme Court directs the Union of India to file a Draft Scheme for water sharing.

subject: Wildlife and Biodiversity
title: Supreme Court order regarding reintroduction of Cheetahs from Africa to suitable sites in India, 10/04/2018
summary: By way of this application, the reintroduction of the Cheetahs from Africa is sought to be made in some other places in addition to Kuno, Shivpuri (Madhya Pradesh). Apex Court directs reply to be filed within six weeks.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Supreme Court order regarding diversion and regularization of Eksali land and Dali plots in Thane and Raigad, Maharashtra, 10/04/2018
summary: The matter relates to diversion and regularization of 13495.6133 hectares of Eksali land and 8037.0848 hectares of Dali Plots in Thane and Raigad Districts (Maharashtra). Application along with report of CEC listed for consideration on 25/04/2018.

subject: Forests
title: Supreme Court order regarding Delhi Jal Board permission for use of 1.6 acres of forest land falling in Sanjay Van, 10/04/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: The report submitted by CEC has given a site specific recommendation which states that as the water pipeline project is in public interest and will benefit about 1.75 lakh residents of the area CEC recommends the Apex Court to consider permitting Delhi Jal Board to use 1.6 acres forest land in Sanjay Van on the condition that : i) Delhi Jal Board will obtain clearance under Section 2 of the Forest (Conservation) Act, 1980 ii) DJB shall deposit 5% of the sanctioned project cost with the Ridge Management Board Fund which shall be used by the Delhi Forest Department for conservation and development of Delhi Ridge. Supreme Court accepts the report of the CEC.

subject: Environment
title: Supreme Court order regarding non-utilization of funds lying with the government meant for the benefit of the people, 10/04/2018
summary: Supreme Court Directs: i) The Secretary in the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change, Government of India is directed to make a compilation of all the funds and the amount lying in each of those funds as on 31st March, 2018. ii) The Secretary in the Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change is further directed to give the Court indication on how the amount of up to Rs.1,00,000 crores is intended to be utilized and areas where it should not be utilized.

subject: Environment
title: Supreme Court order regarding provision of clean drinking water to residents living around Union Carbide plant, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh, 10/04/2018
summary: The issue relates to provision for clean drinking water to residents living around the Union Carbide plant and steps to control spreading of toxic waste, Bhopal, Madhya Pradesh. Supreme Court directs Union of India to file affidavit.

subject: Wildlife and Biodiversity
title: Supreme Court order regarding reintroduction of Cheetahs from Africa to suitable sites in India, 10/04/2018
summary: The issue relates to reintroduction of Cheetahs from Africa to suitable sites in India identified by the Wildlife Institute of India based on a detailed site specific action plan. By way of this application, the reintroduction of the Cheetahs from Africa is sought to be made in some other places in addition to Kuno, Shivpuri (Madhya Pradesh). Apex Court directs reply to be filed within six weeks.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Order of the High Court of Delhi regarding Monsanto's appeal for patents on its BT cotton seeds in India, 11/04/2018
summary: Monsanto claims that the patent is a biotech invention containing the infusion of Bt gene into the cotton genome. The Bt. bacterium eradicates pests afflicting the cotton plant. Monsanto states that the patent does not cover plants per se, but does cover components that can be termed microbiological processes and microorganisms, thus patentable under the Patents Act. Delhi High Court while rejecting the Appeal said Monsanto can apply for registration under the PV Act (within three months of this judgment). Delhi High Court noted that "the denial of a positive order" would result in violation of provisions of the Essential Commodities Act and would deprive the farmers the right to access to seeds that were hitherto available to them.

subject: Environment
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding regarding compensation to persons affected by oil spillage due to collision of ships Kamarajar Port, Chennai on 28/01/2017
respondent: Secretary To Government of Tamil Nadu
summary: The issue relates to compensation to persons affected by oil spillage due to collision of ships M. T. Dawn Kanchipuram and MT BW Maple near Kamarajar Port, Chennai on 28/01/2017. Non-disbursement of compensation has been brought to the notice of Madras High Court. Rs.141 crores has now been deposited with the Government by the insurers of the ships involved and meant for disbursing the same to the above said category of persons. Disbursement of due compensation to those eligible be done by the Director of Fisheries, Chennai, within four weeks.

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
title: Supreme Court judgement regarding the question of granting registration to practice medicines to the ‘Paramparya Vaidyas’ of Kerala, 13/04/2018
summary: The appellants have contended that in the State of Kerala, a large number of persons are practicing in Sidha/Unani/Ayurveda system of medicines known as ‘Paramparya Vaidyas’, which are in vogue for a long time. They have acquired knowledge and experience from their gurus and parents and by continued practice over a long period of time they have acquired the requisite expertise. The enactment of the Travancore-Cochin Medical Practitioners Act 1953, Section 38 empowered the State Government to regulate the qualifications and to provide for the registration of practitioners of modern medicine. The Supreme Court while dismissing the Application said that persons having no recognized and approved qualifications, having little knowledge about the indigenous medicines, are becoming medical practitioners and playing with the lives of thousands and millions of people. A number of unqualified, untrained quacks are posing a great risk to the entire society and playing with the lives of people without having the requisite training and education in the science from approved institutions. The Travancore-Cochin Medical Practitioners Act, 1953 as well as the Indian Medicine Central Council Act, 1970 were also enacted on the similar lines.

subject: Forests
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding maintenance of green cover along highways, 13/04/2018
respondent: Secretary, MORTH (Ministry of Road Transport and Highways) & Others
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: The States were asked to furnish the following information: a. Stretch of roads in different areas in the State where trees have been felled and the areas identified for compensatory afforestation. b. The number of trees proposed to be felled. MOEF has submitted that the requisite information has not been given by : 1. State of Jammu & Kashmir, 2. NCT of Delhi 3. State of Karnataka, 4. State of Manipur, 5. State of Maharashtra, 6. State of Telangana 7. State of Arunachal Pradesh. NGT grants by way of last opportunity time up to 27th April, 2018 to the aforesaid states to furnish information to MoEF, failing which they would be saddled with cost of Rs. 5,000/- per day, thereafter till the information is submitted.

subject: Water Pollution
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding untreated waste being discharge in River Yamuna, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, 13/04/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT directs District Magistrate, Mathura to file an affidavit mentioning the total number of STPs in City of Mathura, when was it established, its capacity, whether these STPs are equipped with updated technology and how much of waste is being treated by the STPs in the City of Mathura.

subject: Mining
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding illegal mining in the state of Uttar Pradesh, 16/04/2018
judge_name: Jawad Rahim, Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT directs the State of Uttar Pradesh to secure factual information regarding legal or illegal mining in the jurisdiction of each Deputy Commissioner/District Magistrate who shall submit report within two weeks. They may also indicate in the report as to whether those persons who are engaged in the permissible mining are adhering to the sustainable mining guidelines of 2016 issued in this regard. In the meanwhile, if there is any illegal mining going on, the State shall ensure its stoppage forthwith and report in this regard be also filed.

subject: Energy
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding imposition 70% of Safeguard Duty on import of Solar Cells, 16/04/2018
petitioner: M/s Shapoorji Pallonji Infrastructure Capital Co Ltd.
summary: Madras High Court while dismissing the Application of solar industry categorically stated that "the scope of interference, in matters, which have huge economic impact, is very narrow. As a matter of fact, actions instituted in courts such as the instant Writ Petition have portents of derailing decisions, which could have a cascading impact and inflict resultant damage, not only on the Domestic Industry in issue, but even on industries, which are vertically integrated to the Domestic Industry, as also on their employees and industrial labour, which perhaps at times courts cannot monetarily quantify". The Court agreed with the contention of the Respondents (Ministry of Finance and Directorate General of Safeguards) that “duty” is nothing but “tax” and there is no need for any compliance of natural justice before imposing tax, which is a legislative function.

subject: Wildlife and Biodiversity
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding euthanasia for ailing temple elephant, Salem, Tamil Nadu, 16/04/2018
summary: Madras High Court allows euthanasia to be performed so that the elephant is relieved from prolonged agony and suffering. Euthanasia shall be performed as per the rules, regulations and guidelines with regard to performance of euthanasia.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding illegal bandhs and fisheries detrimental to the existence of Sundarbans, West Bengal, 16/04/2018
summary: NGT directs the State of West Bengal to file status report on the removal of illegal bandhs and fisheries as well as on the plantation of the mangroves.

subject: Industry
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding fire cracker units operating in West Bengal, 16/04/2018
summary: An affidavit filed in NGT gives information that the State Government is taking steps to establish clusters for setting fire cracker units in different districts for which purpose areas have been earmarked in the South 24 Parganas and for the districts of Hooghly, Howrah, Murshidabad and Burdwan. NGT demands a report on this matter. NGT also directs the West Bengal PCB to place before the Court the present status of the consents granted to the various fire cracker units.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding cases of fire at Ghazipur landfill, Delhi, 17/04/2018
judge_name: Jawad Rahim, Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: East Delhi Municipal Corporation has failed to issue a statement on steps taken to avert instances of fire. Also the report from NCT Delhi regarding investigation about causes resulting in fire instances has not been filed. NGT Principal Bench while taking a stern view of "non compliance and indifferent attitude of the authorities concerned" said factual information about the steps taken or being taken is essential to avoid "perishing of the life of the people".

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
court_involved: High Court of Punjab and Haryana
title: Order of the High Court of Punjab and Haryana regarding monkey attacks on humans, Chandigarh, 17/04/2018
summary: Chandigarh Administration states that the monkey is a scheduled animal protected under the Wildlife (Protection) Act, 1972 and the administration is finding it difficult to control the monkey menace as monkeys are straying into the city area because of the availability of food by the residents. To control the monkey menace Forests and Wildlife Department have suggested the following measures: a. Patrolling in the affected areas will be further intensified by Department of Forests and Wildlife. b. Forests and Wildlife Department shall plant more fruit bearing species in the available patches in the forest areas so that food is available in the forest for the monkeys. c. Issue appropriate directions to Municipal Corporation, Chandigarh to get all the garbage bins covered so that the monkeys do not get to pick up discarded food from these bins. d. Forests and Wildlife Department will request Municipal Corporation, Chandigarh to amend its Bye-Laws wherein feeding monkeys shall be an offence and shall be fined as being done by Shimla Municipal Corporation.

subject: Energy
title: Supreme Court order regarding sale of good quality coal in the garb of rejects to M/S Hindalco, 23/04/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: This is an application filed as a result of an Inquiry Report of the CEC dated 11th May, 2005. The report of the CEC concerns sale of good quality coal in the garb of rejects to M/s. Hindalco. Orders were passed by this Court on 6th November, 2009 requiring an inquiry to be made at the highest level in the Ministry of Home Affairs. As a result of the orders passed by this Court on 6th November, 2009, a report of the Union Home Secretary has been filed. A copy each of this report has been given to learned Additional Solicitor General and to learned amicus curiae.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: Order of the Delhi High Court regarding solid waste management in Delhi, 24/04/2018
respondent: Government of NCT of Delhi & Others
summary: A letter dated 20th April, 2018 has been received from Sunita Narain, Director General, Centre for Science and Environment seeking more time to place the report regarding E-waste management. Delhi High Court directs the report to be filed before the next date of hearing (22/05/2018). Ankit Gupta, Local Commissioner has handed over a CD containing a recording of the factual position on an inspection by him and other reporters of ABP News Network in different parts of Delhi with regard to the status and position of garbage collection and disposal. Municipal Commissioners of North Delhi, South Delhi and East Delhi Municipal Corporations have assured the Court that they shall address the situation on solid waste management on war footing and take every possible step to ensure that the problem is addressed. It is directed that stringent steps to enforce the penal provisions under the solid waste management shall be taken by the municipal corporations.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding Delhi sealing drive, 24/04/2018
summary: Officiating Chairman of the Central Ground Water Board K.C. Naik has been requested to inform the Court the status of ground water level in 20 points in Delhi from the year 2000 onwards every five years including for the year 2017/2018 to understand whether there has been a depletion of ground water and in which area and to what extent. Amicus curiae brings to the notice of the Apex Court the Order passed by Supreme Court on 27/08/2007 informing that construction is being carried out in unauthorized colonies. Court notes that this is possible as building and other bye-laws do not apply to these unauthorized colonies. Supreme Court directs that there should not be any further construction in unauthorized colonies including on public land beyond the existing building and other bye-laws. Consequently, all building and construction activity in the unauthorized colonies including on public land is stopped with immediate effect beyond the existing building and other bye-laws applicable to authorized colonies. The concerned authorities will ensure compliance. A Task Force will be constituted to ensure that the orders of the Supreme Court and applicable bye-laws are implemented and encroachments as well as unauthorized constructions are removed.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding solid waste management in India, 24/04/2018
petitioner: In Re: Outrage as Parents End Life After Child's Dengue
summary: No affidavit has been filed by the States of Manipur and Meghalaya. Supreme Court directs a policy to be prepared by the States in terms of Rule 11 and Rule 15 of the Solid Waste Management Rules, 2016.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding non-compliance of environmental regulations by hotels operating in A&N Islands, 26/04/2018
petitioner: Andaman Chamber of Commerce Industry & Others/ Hotel Sentinel & Others
summary: Counsel for the A&N Pollution Control Committee informs the Court that inspections conducted reveal large scale non-compliance with regard to 84 hotels and resorts as well as 19 automobile service centres as they were found not to have functional STPs/ETPs. NGT Eastern Bench directs the Chief Secretary, A&N Administration, the Principal Secretary, Environment and Forest, A&N Islands and the Chairman and the Member Secretary, A&N Pollution Control Committee to comply with the following:- (i) The Pollution Control Committee to submit report on further action taken consequential to the notices of closure and the reported non-compliance of the closure orders; (ii) The Chief Secretary, A&N Administration and the Principal Secretary, Environment and Forest to submit a report on the discharge of effluent, waste water and municipal solid waste in the coastal areas. They shall also file a report on the mitigation measures taken for the protection of marine ecology which would include the coral reefs and other vulnerable marine flora and fauna.

subject: Wildlife and Biodiversity
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding brick kilns operating within the buffer zone of the eco sensitive zone of Dalma Wildlife Sanctuary, Jamshedpur, Jharkhand, 26/04/2018
summary: The issue relates to brick kilns operating within the buffer zone of the eco sensitive zone of Dalma Wildlife Sanctuary, Jamshedpur, Jharkhand. Also whether the brick kilns have valid consents to operate under the Air (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1981 and the Water (Prevention and Control of Pollution) Act, 1974 and Environmental Clearance under the EIA Notification, 2006. NGT Eastern Bench directs the Jharkhand PCB to issue notice upon all the brick kiln owners, directing them to comply with the requirements to be compiled with by them. The State PCB shall then decide on the merit of each of case of the applicants and submit a report. Copies of the letter furnished to the Applicants as directed above, shall also be forwarded to the Department of Forest and other State authorities for their information.

subject: Mining
court_involved: High Court of Punjab and Haryana
title: Order of the High Court of Punjab & Haryana regarding mining in Aravali area, District Mahendergarh, Haryana, 26/04/2018
summary: The issue relates to mining lease for an area measuring 79.32 hectares in Aravali area, Village Musnota, Tehsil Narnaul, District Mahendergarh for extraction of quartz, feldspar and barites, all major minerals. The petitioner has argued that the area of 79.32 hectares has been subjected to mining since 1977 and is not covered under the Aravali Area or afforestation and had the leased area been included in the list of Aravali Plantation, there would be no question of mining till 2007. The Court finds no evidence to obstruct the mining rights of the petitioner "by simply classifying it as Aravali Area without even having any authenticated official record to identify it as such". The Court accepts the submission of the mining officer that mining rights (mining in the leased area of 79.32 hectares, governed by the terms of the lease and other necessary essentials) of the petitioner would be made operational if the rent is paid.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Supreme Court order regarding loans for the incoming agricultural season, India, 02/05/2018
petitioner: National Bank of Agriculture and Rural Development (NABARD) Manager & Others
summary: Supreme Court directs that farmers whose loan amount is upto Rs.1,00,000/- (Rupees one lakh) can receive loan for the incoming agricultural season. This order shall be subject to order/orders as may be passed in the Special Leave Petition (16087/2017) which would be listed for hearing on 28th August, 2018.

subject: Forests
title: Supreme Court order regarding construction of International Craft Complex in morphological Ridge area, Vasant Kunj, New Delhi, 03/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: A CEC report on this matter was placed before the Court which was accepted by the Apex Court subject to some conditions: i) The NBCC (India) Pvt. Ltd. Shall deposit 5% of project cost with the Ridge Management Board Fund for conservation and protection of Delhi Ridge ii) the NBCC will deposit the cost of undertaking compensatory planting of 135 plants and NBCC/Ministry of Textiles will make available sufficient land for undertaking compensatory planting of 135 plants iii) the User Agency shall maintain a green belt of trees all along the periphery of the proposed site and create at least one percolation pond in the north eastern side of the plot to facilitate ground water recharge.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Supreme Court order regarding utilization of land for the widening of National Highway from Dhaula Kuan, Delhi, 03/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: It is stated by the counsel appearing for the NHAI that 21.52 hectares of land in Yamuna Flood Plain has been handed over to the NHAI. It is further stated that 5% of the Project cost has been deposited with the Ridge Management Board.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Supreme Court order regarding restructuring of Tribunal System, 07/05/2018
summary: The issue deals with the restructuring of Tribunal System in the light of constitutional scheme as interpreted in decisions of the Supreme Court. Concept of Tribunals was evolved to decongest the court system and to provide speedy and inexpensive justice. Separation of powers and independence of judiciary are the constitutional concepts which have to be followed in setting up of Tribunals. Functioning of Tribunals is required to be reviewed on the test of speedy and inexpensive quality justice. Supreme Court directs setting up of a committee which will have interaction with all stakeholders and suggest a mechanism consistent with the constitutional scheme as interpreted by the Supreme Court and decide: on the creation of a regular cadre for recruitment for Tribunals; look into the matter of amending the scheme of direct appeals to the Supreme Court so that the orders of Tribunals are subject to jurisdiction of the High Courts; conferring jurisdiction on existing courts as special Courts or Tribunals.

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
title: Supreme Court order regarding functioning of mid-day meal scheme, 08/05/2018
summary: Supreme Court directs the petitioner to give an up-to-date status on affidavit with regard to the functioning of the Mid Day Meal Scheme from the web-site of the Government of India and the State Governments. The cut-off date would be 30.06.2018.

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
title: Supreme Court order regarding protection and care of the rights of the elderly, 08/05/2018
summary: Amicus Curiae has submitted before the Court that he will prepare model guidelines for the operation of old age homes, pensions and health care facilities. He will also prepare a chart giving the details of the facilities that are available and the budget available and required.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding unauthorised constructions in Delhi and its effect on groundwater, 08/05/2018
summary: Central Ground Water Board has filed a report on the status of ground water which shows that in areas categorized as over exploited (as per Ground Water Resources Estimation of 2013) from May 200 to May 2017 water level declined rate varied from 0.5 m/year to more than 2 m/year at places. Major part of Delhi is under Overexploited and Semi Critical category and in such areas water levels are showing persistent declining trend during last two decades. Supreme Court urges the concerned authorities to look into the Report to avoid a water crisis. Supreme Court directs the Ministry of Water Resources of the Government of India and the Delhi Government as well as the Delhi Pollution Control Committee to tell the Court about the possible solutions.

subject: Water Resources
title: Supreme Court order regarding Cauvery Draft Scheme, 08/05/2018
summary: Supreme Court directs the Secretary, Ministry of Water Resources, River Development & Ganga Rejuvenation, Government of India, to remain present with the draft Scheme. Supreme Court directs for the personal appearance of the Secretary so that the authorities under the Scheme can implement the judgment passed by the Court as the same has the status of the decree.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding sealing drive in Delhi against unauthorised constructions, 08/05/2018
summary: Report No. 118 of the Monitoring Committee was placed before the Court and it deals with alleged unauthorised constructions in Khan Market as well as in Sanjay Market. It has also been pointed out that the seals of the premises sealed on 2nd August, 2007 in Sanjay Market have since been tampered with and huge multi storeyed buildings have come up on all the sealed premises. Even some of the premises have been converted to residential premises. Supreme Court makes it clear that if there are any areas where there are violations which have come to the notice of the Monitoring Committee, they may be sent directly to the Special Task Force. For the purpose of the accountability, Supreme Court wants the Special Task Force to meet once in a fortnight along with concerned officials of the various corporations and the Zonal authorities to ensure that the orders of this Court are implemented in letter and spirit.

subject: Mining
title: Supreme Court judgement regarding reservation of lands for government companies or corporations owned and controlled by the State Government under MMDR Act 1957, 08/05/2018
petitioner: M/s. Geomysore Services (I) Pvt. Ltd. & Others
respondent: M/s. Hutti Goldmines Co. Ltd. & Others
act_referred: Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulations ) Act 1957
summary: The issue relates to reservation of lands for government companies or corporations owned and controlled by the State Government under section 17A (2) of the Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulations) Act, 1957. There are gold mines in the State of Karnataka and parties are litigating in respect of their rights to exploit those mines. The main highlights of the Supreme Court Judgement of May 08, 2018 are the following: (i) The State Government being the owner of the land and minerals, has a right to make a proposal to the Central Government to reserve lands not held under a prospecting licence or mining lease for exploitation by the State Government companies or undertakings but approval of the Central Government is necessary; (ii) the Central Government can not only take into consideration factors of national security or public interest but also economic factors, the policy of the Government and all such other factors which are relevant to decide the issue whether the land should be reserved for exploitation only by State Government Undertakings; (iii) Supreme Court sets aside the judgment of the High Court passed in W.P. No.25899 of 2011 on 03.04.2012 and the decision of the Central Government dated 31.05.2011 is upheld and the State of Karnataka is directed to consider the case of Geomysore and Deccan for grant of Prospecting Licence (PL) in accordance with the provisions of the Act as they now stand amended in the year 2015.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding closure of the Common Bio-medical Waste Treatment Facility at Bhilai, State of Chhattisgarh, 08/05/2018
petitioner: M/s E Tech Projects Pvt. Ltd.
summary: The Appelant (M/s E Tech Projects Pvt. Ltd.) contends before the Court that they were not provided the opportunity to present their case. NGT Central Zonal Bench directs Chhattisgarh Environment Conservation Board to accord an opportunity of hearing to the appellant and thereafter pass a fresh order on merits, in accordance with law.

subject: Air Pollution
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding garbage being set on fire leading to air pollution, Janakpuri, Delhi, 08/05/2018
summary: Abmber Sachdvea the Applicant has been permitted to file the photographs in the Registry and such filing the Registry will issue Notice enclosing the photographs to the NCT of Delhi and SDMC to file their response.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding regarding unauthorized constructions in Kasauli, Himachal Pradesh, 09/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: The Indian Express and the Tribune Dated 2nd May 2018 Regarding Kasauli Incident
summary: Supreme Court directs the State of Himachal Pradesh to file a status report within a period of two months giving information on the following issues : a) The names and designation of the officers who were posted at the time when unauthorized construction was being carried out b) Guidelines, if any, that have been framed by the State of Himachal Pradesh to ensure that unauthorized constructions do not take place at the scale as happened in Kasauli. If guidelines have not been framed, they should be framed expeditiously c) Specific steps that are being taken by the State of Himachal Pradesh so that there is no unauthorized construction in other parts of the State and how the problem is proposed to be tackled by the State d) What does the State of Himachal Pradesh propose to do with the debris which will remain after the demolition of the unauthorized constructions.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Supreme Court order regarding encroachment of Pachmarhi cantonment land, Madhya Pradesh, 09/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: Supreme Court has been informed that out of 1001.582 hectares of Cantonment land belonging to the Army which is included in the Panchmarhi Wild Life Sanctuary notified under the Wild Life (Protection) Act, 1972, 607.582 hectares is non-forest Cantonment land and 395 hectares is deemed forest land being part of Cantonment land belonging to the Army. In the meeting held under the aegis of the Secretary in the Ministry of Defence, it was agreed that 234 hectares out of 395 hectares should be kept as a deemed forest under the control of the Army authorities. However, since the entire 395 hectares of land is a deemed forest, Apex Court opines that that the entire land of 395 hectares be maintained as a deemed forest under the control of the Army authorities. Supreme Court rules that this 395 hectares will continue to remain as deemed forest and can be utilised by the Army authorities for jungle warfare, but no trees will be damaged or cut in that area. The Army authorities has also agreed to construct a Sewage Treatment Plant (STP).

subject: Forests
title: Supreme Court order regarding permission to cut 234 trees for pipeline under Agra Water Supply, District Mathura & Agra, Uttar Pradesh, 09/05/2018
summary: The prayer in the application is for permission to cut 234 trees to complete the project of laying of conduit pipe line to enable the Ganga water to reach Agra for the purpose of supply of drinking water to Agra city in the coming summer months. CEC was asked to look into the averments made in the application and submit a report. The report apprises that as the project is in public interest, that the felling of trees is unavoidable for laying of the pipeline and the project authorities have offered to undertake planting of 2500 trees in Shekhoopur Mandapur Village in the designated land at project cost in lieu of the 234 trees now marked for felling, the CEC recommends that the Apex Court "may consider granting permission for felling of 234 trees in District Agra and District Mathura to implement the project of laying conduit pipeline under the Agra Water Supply (Ganga Jal)" falling in the TTZ in the State of Uttar Pradesh subject to certain conditions. Counsel appearing on behalf of U.P. Jal Nigam assured the Court that the recommendations made by the CEC will be adhered to and followed in letter and spirit. He also assures that the trees that are required to be planted will be looked after. Supreme Court directs U.P. Forest Department to look into this because it has come to the notice of the Court that the mortality rate of trees being planted towards afforestation work in some places is as high as 80%.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Supreme Court judgement on whether a Parliamentary Standing Committee (PSC) report can be placed reliance upon for adjudication of a fact in issue, 09/05/2018
summary: The main points of the judgement are the following: 1. When a party relies on any fact stated in the Parliamentary Committee Report as the matter of noticing an event or history no exception can be taken on such reliance of the report. However, no party can be allowed to 'question'   or 'impeach' report of Parliamentary Committee. 2. Admissibility of a Parliamentary Committee Report  in evidence does not mean that facts stated in the Report stand proved. When issues of facts come before a Court of law for adjudication, the Court is to decide the issues on the basis of evidence and materials brought before it.

subject: Water Resources
title: Order of the Delhi High Court regarding repair of Delhi sub-branch canal which is leading to loss of water, 10/05/2018
summary: Delhi High Court while stressing on the urgency for repair of the canal said the delay would lead to loss of water badly needed for human purpose. High Court directs the State of Haryana to commence the process of tendering of the work of repairs to the Delhi Sub-Branch Canal and to ensure the process of award and completion of the work is effected at the earliest, in any case, not later than by 15th June, 2018.

subject: Forests
title: Supreme Court order regarding use of Delhi Ridge land for the widening of National Highway, Delhi, 10/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: NCT of Delhi has issued a demand notice on the National Highways Authority of India (NHAI) to the extent of Rs.6,62,000,91/- (Rupees six crore sixty two lakhs ninety-one only). NHAI has stated that the amount will be paid within two weeks. As soon as the amount is received, the Forest Department of the NCT of Delhi will start the afforestation process.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Supreme Court judgement regarding rate of compensation for land acquired for a percolation tank, village Pimpri Mokhad, District Akola, Maharashtra, 11/05/2018
summary: The High Court had reduced the compensation to Rs.50,000/- per hectare for irrigated land and Rs.9,500/- per hectare for dry land from Rs.1,62,500/- per hectare awarded (uniformly) by the Reference Court. The High Court has also set aside the award of compensation to the claimant at Rs.1200/- per orange tree. The land in contention is survey no. 32 measuring 9 Hectares and 20 Areas of village Pimpri Mokhed, Taluka Karanja, District Akola, Maharashtra was acquired for the purpose of construction of ‘Percolation Tank’ at village Pimpri Mokhad. Supreme Court sets aside the Judgement of the High Court and said that the claimant are entitled to all statutory benefits including solatium and interest as per law.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Judgement of the High Court of Uttarakhand regarding declaration of rural self governing institutions like gram panchayat to an urban local body by converting it into a Nagar Panchayat, 14/05/2018
summary: The main matter relates to notification issued on 05.04.2018 by which 73 villages were proposed to be included in the Nagar Palika Kotdwar. High Court declares that the power to define an urban area, in its various forms, is a discretionary power of the Governor and that the notifications dated 05.04.2018 have not been issued by the authority empowered under the law. The notifications under Article 243Q of the Constitution of India read with Sections 3 & 4 of the U.P. Municipalities Act are the notifications, which have to be issued by none other than the Governor, in his discretionary powers. Since this has not been done, the notifications do not have the validity of law.

subject: Environment
title: Supreme Court order regarding misuse of environment protection funds, 14/05/2018
petitioner: In Re: T. N. Godavarman Thirumulpad
summary: Supreme Court observed that prima facie it appears that the funds are being used for the purposes other than what was intended from the affidavit submitted by the counsel for the State of Meghalaya. Apex Court requests the assistance of ASG with regard to appropriate and proper utilization of funds not only by the State of Meghalaya but by all other States.

subject: Water Resources
title: Supreme Court order regarding draft management scheme for Cauvery, 14/05/2018
summary: The Central Government represented by the Ministry of Water Resources, River Development and Ganga Rejuvenation filed the draft scheme. The States of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Union Territory of Puducherry has been given copies of the draft scheme "only to examine whether the said Scheme is in consonance with the judgment of this Court".

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding Action Plan for monitoring of construction activities in Delhi, 15/05/2018
summary: Attorney General has placed before the Apex Court the Action Plan for monitoring of all construction activities in Delhi and fixing of responsibility in case of violations of Master Plan, unified building Bye-laws and other illegal construction activities. Supreme Court directs that the Action Plan be published in leading English newspapers circulated in Delhi for three consecutive days over the next ten days and in leading Hindi newspapers circulated in Delhi in Hindi for three consecutive days over the next ten days. Supreme Court also partially modified its order dated 6th March 2018 on the amendment of the Master Plan. Objections to the proposed amendments to the Master Plan for Delhi will be considered and amendments will be notified by the Central Government only after giving a notice period of 15 days for submitting objections. The final decision of the Central Government would be taken keeping the interest of the people of Delhi and future generations in mind as well as the statutory requirements. In the meanwhile  the Special Task Force to deal with unauthorised constructions and the Monitoring Committee will continue with its duties and responsibilities.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Supreme Court order regarding qualification applicable for appointment in Tribunal/ Commission, 16/05/2018
summary: Supreme Court in the Order categorically states that " wherever qualification required for appointment to a Tribunal/Commission is of a former Chief Justice or a former Supreme Court Judge, and no suitable person of that category is available, it will be open to make appointment of any suitable former Judge of a High Court till any legislative amendment in that regard is brought out so that a Tribunal/Commission may not remain headless". Apex Court further makes it clear that the constitution of the Committee is the responsibility of the government.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: Order of the High Court of Delhi regarding municipal solid waste rules 2016, 16/05/2018
summary: A PIL was filed in the Delhi High Court which challenged the municipal solid waste rules 2016 on the context that the rules hold individuals and not the local bodied responsible for segregation of garbage at source. Delhi High Court also appointed Sunita Narain, Director General of the Centre for Science and Environment (CSE) as amicus curiae in the matter and listed the matter for 24th September, 2018.

subject: Water Resources
title: Supreme Court order regarding release of drinking water for Delhi from Haryana, 16/05/2018
summary: Apex Court expects the Delhi Jal Board to meet over the next couple of days and sort out the matter amicably between the State of Delhi and the State of Haryana.

subject: Governance & Institutions
title: Supreme Court judgement regarding implementation of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act, 2005, 18/05/2018
summary: Apex Court emphasised on the fact that there cannot be any justifiable reason to delay payment of wages or justifiable denial of compensation for delayed payment of wages. Any delay in payment of wages or compensation violates statutory provisions. Supreme Court directs the Central Government through the Ministry of Rural Development, in consultation with the State Governments and Union Territory Administrations to prepare an urgent time bound mandatory program for the payment of wages and compensation to the workers.

subject: Water Resources
title: Supreme Court order regarding draft Cauvery Management Scheme
act_referred: Inter State River Water Disputes Act 1956
summary: Union of India assures the Apex Court that the draft scheme will be taken to its logical end in accordance with law. The Court hoped that the draft scheme will be notified in the Official Gazette and given effect to before the onset of the monsoon.

subject: Industry
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding industries violating environmental norms, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, 18/05/2018
respondent: Uttar Pradesh Pollution Control Board & Others
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT makes it clear that the question of refusing permission to operate is not within NGT's domain but it is that of the Appellate authority (SPCB).

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding waste dumping at Basai Wetland, Gurugram, Haryana, 18/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT orders the matter to be heard on priority and has listed it for 30th May, 2018.

subject: Industry
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding pollution caused by industries established in Eldeco SIDCUL Industrial Park in Sitarganj, Uttarakhand, 18/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: The matter relates to the complete disregard of environmental laws and pollution norms by large numbers of industries established in ELDECO (SIDCUL) industrial park which are situated in the vicinity of the village Siddh Garbyang, Kalyanpur, Tehsil-Sitarganj, District-Udham Singh Nagar, Uttarakhand. There are more than 100 industries coming up in the area. Some of these industrial units are spewing black soot which deposite black dust on the houses of the villagers. NGT directs CPCB to inspect the polluting industries and take samples of water/air. On confirmation about they being polluting, give a list of such industry to SIDCUL. Upon receipts of such list SIDCUL and Uttarakhand Pollution Control Board shall immediately stop the functioning of such industries.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding burning of the garbage in open by the New Okhla Industrial Development Authority, Delhi, 22/05/2018
judge_name: Jawad Rahim, S.P. Wangdi, Nagin Nanda
summary: NGT directs joint inspection to be conducted by CPCB and State Pollution Control Board of the areas indicated in the application and file a report as to whether the garbage is being dumped and burnt as alleged without taking proper recourse in law.

subject: Industry
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding environmental clearance granted to Sterlite Industries Limited, Tuticorin, Tamil Nadu, 23/05/2018
summary: The issue relates to the environmental clearance granted to Sterlite Industries Limited and which is carrying on construction activities on the site for the proposed Copper Smelter Unit II at SIPCOT, Tuticorin. The clearance has, according to the petitioner, been obtained by Vedanta, without the conduct of a public hearing and the requirement for such hearing had been waived on the incorrect representation of Vedanta that Unit II was to be located in Phase II of SIPCOT Industrial Park that had itself been granted approval. Madras High Court directs that the application for renewal of EC submitted by Vedanta shall be processed expeditiously after conduct of mandatory public hearing. In the meanwhile, Vedanta shall cease construction and all other activities on-site proposed Unit-II of the Copper Smelting Plant at Tuticorin with immediate effect.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding rehabilitation of mule operators operating between between Katra and Vaishno Devi shrine, Jammu & Kashmir, 23/05/2018
judge_name: Jawad Rahim, S.P. Wangdi, Nagin Nanda
summary: The issue relates to the finalizing and implementing the Rehabilitation Scheme for people engaged in carrying pilgrims to the Vaishno Devi shrine on horses and mules, which have now been prohibited. NGT expresses displeasure with the Status Report filed by the State of Jammu & Kashmir before the Court and directed the Secretary of the State of Jammu & Kashmir to answer for the default committed by the State in the implementation of the Rehabilitation Scheme.

subject: Water Pollution
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding pollution caused to River Beas and Satluj due to pollutants being discharged from industries, Punjab, 24/05/2018
judge_name: Jawad Rahim, S.P. Wangdi, Nagin Nanda
summary: National Green Tribunal directs the Central Pollution Control Board and State Pollution Control Board to conduct joint inspections of the areas indicated in the application, collect samples from both the rivers including the spots alleged in the application. The collection point shall be upstream and downstream and from the discharge point and also from the drain namely Buddha Nalla. Report of the samples collected shall be prepared by the joint inspection team. The inspection team shall visit the areas in question and submit a report on the death of aquatic animal as indicated in the petition and whether it is related to the alleged pollution and if so, identify the source of pollution/polluters.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: Supreme Court order regarding amendments to the Master Plan for Delhi, 24/05/2018
summary: Apex Court observed that Delhi is being ravaged by unauthorised encroachments and illegal constructions with impunity and none of the civic authorities including the Delhi Development Authority was carrying out its statutory duties and that it is painful to issue directions to authorities to "carry out their mandatory functions in accordance with the law enacted by Parliament". Supreme Court also made it very clear that the people of Delhi has to be taken into confidence with regard to amendments to the Master Plan and rejects the request of the Attorney General to modify the Apex Court's Order Dated 15th May 2018. The Central Governnment has been directed to expeditiously implement the order dated 15th May, 2018 keeping the interest of the public of Delhi in mind.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: Order of the Delhi High Court regarding Delhi Jal Board's tender on mechanised cleaning of sewers in Delhi, 29/05/2018
judge_name: S. Ravindra Bhat, A. K. Chawla
summary: The issue relates to the conditions in the tender issued by the Delhi Jal Board inviting bids for mechanized cleaning of sewers in the city of Delhi. One of the eligibility criteria for bidders which the petitioner complains about is that preference would be given to "bidders who belong to Scheduled Caste and Schedule Tribe community who engaged in the manual scavenging and their dependent as per article 46 of the Constitution as mentioned in THE PROHIBITIONOF EMPLOYMENTAS MANUAL SCAVENGERS AND THEIR REHABILFTATIONACT, 2013". High Court of Delhi while dismissing the petition said that " the object of such preference is plainly to enable the meaningful participation of the most marginalized section, i.e. workers involved in manual scavenging, and scheduled caste/scheduled tribe communities". The state, i.e., DJB, in our opinion, had a compelling interest in promoting the welfare of these class of citizens, while conceiving and implementing this system of preferences, in the impugned NIT.

subject: Waste Management, Disposal
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding solild waste issues, Govardhan, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, 30/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: NGT Order emphasised on a survey to know as to how many sewerage lines are coming from the neighboring houses and joining Mansi Ganga. All such lines needs to be completely stopped and alternative route be looked into. Also a thorough survey in respect of collection of solid waste of Goverdhan and Radha Kund needs to be done. The land fill site is already earmarked. Further it is to be looked into as to whether the area earmarked for waste treatment plant is sufficient or not.

subject: Water Resources
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding supply of treated sewage water for gardening purposes in Vasant Kunj, Delhi, 31/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: This execution application has been filed by the applicant in the month of December 2017 for compliance of the order dated 26-10-2017 in which the Court had passed directions that DDA/MCD shall ensure that DJB shall supply treated sewage water for gardening at the fixed rate which will be the primary responsibility of the public authority. The residents, DDA/MCD and DJB were prohibited to use fresh water for gardening purpose. As per the order it was the joint responsibility of DDA and MCD to ensure that the pipeline is made effectively operative and duly maintained. It has come to the notice of the Court that even the work with regard to the pipeline have not been started by DDA so far. NGT directs DDA to pay a compensation of Rs. 1 lac and the directions issued to DDA by NGT to be compiled upon within four weeks. In the meanwhile, DJB shall continue to supply treated water for the purpose of gardening.

subject: Forests
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding construction work at the reserve forest of Bandh Ki Gadi, Amagarh, Jaipur, Rajasthan, 31/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: Respondents including Jaipur Development Authority are restrained from interfering in the reserve forest of Bandh Ki Gadi, Amagarh which consist of Village Galta and Jamdoli by doing any work including construction of any nature and changing the nature of the forest area.

subject: Environment
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding proper disposal of the offerings at the temples, Govardhan, Mathura, Uttar Pradesh, 31/05/2018
judge_name: Raghuvendra S. Rathore, Satyawan Singh Garbyal
summary: Counsel for the State of Uttar Pradesh informs the Court that ETPs would be installed for the proper disposal of milk offerings. The Court has been informed that there are 32 kunds in Giriraj Parikarma and if there is any obstruction to the flow of water then it would be removed and that 155 encroachments over forest land have been removed and the land has been taken over by the Forest Department.

subject: Land, Agriculture, Animal Care and Fisheries
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding grant of permission for Jallikattu, Poolankurichi Village, Sivagangai District, Tamil Nadu, 01/06/2018
summary: The matter relates to grant of permission and necessary protection for conducting the Jallikattu at Poolankurichi Village, Thiruppathur Taluk, Sivagangai District on the eve of Sri Angala Parameswari, Sri Kanavai Karuppar Swamy Temple festival. The Petitioner (P L Ramaiah) is accorded permission to hold Jallikattu after making necessary arrangements and comply with the conditions stipulated in the G.O.MS.No: 7, Animal Husbandry Dairying and Fishery (AH3) department dated 21.01.2017.

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
title: Order of the Uttaranchal High Court regarding the situation of mentally disturbed children in the State of Uttarakhand, 01/06/2018
summary: The State Government is directed to prepare a comprehensive Policy for rehabilitating the mentally disturbed children and patients. All the SSPs/SPs, throughout the State, are directed to ensure that the mentally disturbed patients are not treated by tantriks, quacks etc. and also to ensure that the mentally disturbed patients are not chained/ shackled/fettered/ill-treated or kept in solitary confinement even in the private homes and institutions. The State Government is directed to conduct the Epidemiological Survey Data in the State to determine the mentally retarded/disturbed children through National Institute of Mental Help and Neurosciences, Bangalore (Karnataka) within six months. The State Government is directed to incorporate mental health service into general service at all levels including primary health centers in all health programmes.

subject: Industry
title: Order of the Madras High Court regarding power loom factories illegally operating in Erode, Tamil Nadu, 04/06/2018
summary: The matter relates to power loom factories illegally running in in Survey No.38, 39, Minnakadu Thottam, Thanneerpandalpalayam, Veerappan Chatram Post, Erode, Tamil Nadu. The petitioner complains of unbearable noise as also dust from the power looms. Madras High Court directs the Pollution Control Board to ensure that the Power Looms are not operated beyond the permitted working hours and to ensure that the noise level does not exceed the permissible decibel level.

subject: Energy
title: Judgement of the Delhi High Court regarding the notification issued by the Ministry of Coal for the cancellation of Chhatrasal coal block for Sasan Ultra Mega Power Project, Singrauli, Madhya Pradesh, 06/06/2018
summary: The issue relates to cancellation of coal block Chhatrasal for the Sasan UMPP and the supply of surplus quantity of coal upto a maximum of 9 Million Metric Tons per annum from the coal mines of Moher, Moher-Amlohri and Chhatrasal for the 3960 MW thermal plant owned and managed by Chitrangi Power Pvt. Ltd, a wholly owned subsidiary of Reliance. Reliance states that before the bids there was a clear representation by the respondents that 100% equity of SPL would be transferred to the successful bidder. It is averred that at such time, SPL had allocation of three coal blocks: Moher, Moher-Amlohri Extension and Chhatrasal, having total reserves of 760 Million MT and that the bid was based on these representations that these mines have been allocated to SPL and will be available for the UMPP. Additional Solicitor General on behalf of the Respondents has made detailed submissions and one of the submission made before the Court is that Sasan UMPP is a pithead power plant and has a dedicated coal mine and even if there uncertainty in the supply of coal by Coal India Ltd./SCCL it would not lead to the shutting down of plants. Taking into account the submissions made Delhi High Court dismisses the Application.

subject: Health, Food Safety, Pesticides
title: Judgement of the High Court of Delhi regarding the condition laid down by the Govt. of NCT of Delhi for bids for mid-day cooked meals, Delhi, 06/06/2018
judge_name: S. Ravindra Bhat, A. K. Chawla
summary: The present common petition, by four non-governmental organizations, challenges a tender condition formulated by the Govt. of NCT of Delhi while inviting bids for the mid-day cooked meals scheme formulated by it. The petitioners allege that the eligibility condition of a minimum threshold of Rupees three crores average financial turnover, during the previous three years, is arbitrary. Delhi High Court opines that the eligibility condition (of possessing an average annual turnover of ₹ 3 crores for the preceding 3 years) is arbitrary and unreasonable and is accordingly quashed. Therefore, the NCT of Delhi is directed to appropriately rework the said condition and whilst doing so also factor in a suitable and an appropriate condition enabling two or more NGOs with the requisite experience each and having a certain percentage each of the financial criteria to be eventually worked out, as the minimum requirements to enable wider participation.

subject: Air Pollution
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding registration of BS-IV compliant diesel trucks, Delhi, 28/07/2017
judge_name: Swatanter Kumar, Jawad Rahim, Raghuvendra S. Rathore
summary: Application filed by the Delhi Cantonment Board is allowed by the Tribunal subject to the condition that the diesel trucks of Delhi Cantonment Board which are 10 years old will not be used any more and they will be auctioned for the purpose of dismantling and/or being plied in the area outside of Delhi which have been identified as the area where the ambient air quality is within the prescribed standards. The new trucks would be registered only after this and they shall be used by the Delhi Cantonment Board only for transportation of waste and will not be used for any private purpose.

subject: Habitat & Urbanisation
title: National Green Tribunal order regarding construction in the city of Shimla of Himachal Pradesh in relation to 17 green areas, 01/09/2015
summary: The Tribunal in the present order noted that "despite our orders no study in regard to load bearing capacity of the Hills at Shimla, and impact of further density in construction on sewage system, water supply, collection and disposal of Municipal solid waste, transportation and Environmental ecology has been placed on record".
